measured_by: Solway and Botvinick sequential consumer-choice task
justification: “Here, we review a selection of tasks that have been used to study human planning within a computational framework. Solway and Botvinick task …”
“The two-step task is the simplest task that distinguishes model-free and model-based learning.”

measured_by: Gläscher et al. multi-step decision task
justification: “These modifications allowed Gläscher et al. to dissociate neural correlates of reward prediction errors and state prediction errors.”

measured_by: Wunderlich et al. adversarial two-player minimax task
justification: “This variant … allowed them to study the computational processes underlying forward planning by searching for neural correlates of values of individual branching steps in a minimax decision tree.”

measured_by: Callaway et al. Mouselab-style graph exploration task
justification: “To more directly measure the planning process, they employed a process tracing method inspired by the ‘Mouselab’ paradigm… The sequence in which participants choose to reveal rewards provides insight in the cognitive process by which participants plan.”

measured_by: Snider et al. triangular grid scrolling task
justification: “Participants … receive reward proportional to the size of all disks on that trajectory. … making this one of the most complex tasks in which human planning has been quantitatively modeled.”

measured_by: Huys et al. 8-step graph traversal task
justification: “This task has been used to study how people prune decision trees following a large loss.”
